author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple things:
1) no one is actually a perfectionist. It doesn’t exist. I heard a great story of someone telling (I want to say) Richard Marx that he hadn’t released his record yet cause he’s a perfectionist and RM replied “Bullshit. Name one thing you’ve ever done that’s actually perfect. You’re just scared to move on.”  That story has stuck with me.

2) I’m a fairly decent guitar player, have made an actual career of being paid to do it. And I STILL am either constantly hiring people better than I or recording things note by note and then assembled in protools afterwards. Dr Luke might be the best guitarist I’ve ever been around (and I’ve hung with Blake Mills, Tim Pierce, Phil X), and he CONSTANTLY would just hit record, play the four chords of the song free time, and then cut them up and drop them on the ones or wherever they’re supposed to go in the song. My favorite thing about making records vs performing them live is that on record NO ONE CARES how you got there, just that you did. Unless your groove has something particularly magic to offer I’d get over the one take mentality pretty quick.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I worked with a band at the very beginning that was a three piece with VERY specific rules. 

1) all songs had to be under 2:45
2) guitars and vocals could be doubled for tone, but not parts.
3) bassist sang lead, if there was a harmony the guitarist (not a gifted singer) had to sing it, if there was a third part the drummer had to sing it (couldn’t sing at all)
4) record couldn’t take more than a week to record/mix 

It was the project that convinced Luke I could be a producer; his fav record id done up to that point.

There’s a real value to putting strict limitations on your art, it often brings the most clarity and creativity. Side note: they were terrible technical musicians but just fucking AWESOME.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@BatMeckley is the resident Grammy Loser on this topic, but I’ve made a decent living doing some indie and major label stuff as a vocal producer. 

Deliverables really depend on the producer you’re working with. In my experience it’s 50/50 whether they want tuned or raw, comped or all the takes- etc. 

The key things that keep me getting called are, in no particular order:

Communication. Everybody knows what to expect and what is to be expected. 

Professionalism. The room is clean, mics are up, lighting is right, session is loaded. 

Intuition. All the artistic/personal things. Making the artist feel safe enough to be dangerous, knowing how hard you can push them to get a take, knowing where the line is between their vision and yours, etc…

Sonics. I want my artists to feel expensive when they’re recording, so getting the mic and cue mix right is everything. 

Speed. A comp up by the time they’re done tracking, a quick shine to make it feel special, and a bounce for them to take with them.

Everything else is on a per session basis. I can deliver a fully mixed/tuned vocal and everything in between, so it all depends on communication ahead of time.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Really well framed and important questions here. 

I’ve heard your music, and so first let me say that you’re on the path. This is the work. This is the practice. Just like yoga or meditation or basketball. 

Second, let me say, again, there’s no secret knowledge. There’s only showing up, paying attention, and doing the work consistently. 

Consistency is the only actual key to success. 

So when you look at your finished projects you can’t think about them as failures, only as rungs on the latter you’re climbing. And the only way to see what’s what is to KEEP CLIMBING.

author: popaganda.
content: I’ll add kind of a different angle to this convo….everything mentioned is crucial…play a lot, record, play with others, just reps….but if you want to see big gains TECHNICALLY on something like guitar or piano, you need to break movements down and very very slowly drill the transitions….one note to the next. One chord to the next…really building muscle memory. For a new chord shape…form it very slowly and then let go completely. Repeat many times. Same thing for chord transitions….super slowly between the two. It may seem like it would take too long to practice like that, but doing micro work like that will completely transform your ability on an instrument if you’re judicious and persistent.

author: LAPhill
content: The hard truth is that, if you're going to be a producer recording your own parts, then it's your responsibility to figure out how to make them bang. And learning how to quickly and efficiently work around your limitations is part of the gig. Get really good at knowing where you can punch to hide the seams of comping, regardless of the type of part. Retune the guitar to make chord shapes easier. Split up the part. If you practice THOSE editing skills, your workflow will speed up tremendously. There's no need to concern yourself with being able to play it in one go, or at all, unless you're going to perform it live.

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

author: bobby k
content: I will say this, on the topic of standing up for yourself -- I've seen a couple times in these threads now a general sentiment of accepting that people are gonna kick you around. It felt evident when we were riffing on sliding scale mixing rates last month and it felt evident this morning/last night in here. I'm all in on the greyhound sentiment, I've been a grafter through and through since I was in elementary school skipping homework to double up on piano practice. I once drove 7 hours to buy a Juno-60 on Craigslist and the guy didn't answer the door; I make DUMB life decisions all centered around this non-negotiable gravity towards the art. I can promise I have whatever that obsessive brain disorder thing is that we all keep riffing about (and believe the same for the grand majority here). But can we not practice a little self preservation along the way? Nobody besides your team is really gonna stick up for you; I believe that in line with the all the professional metrics there exists the opportunity/need to set  precedents on how you want to be treated. I don't think this is something that *comes* with being a great producer, I think it's something that *contributes* to someone becoming a great producer. And of course, knowing how to ask for that fairness with a kind/patient/assertive/flexible tone is critical. But if I believe something is a little crooked in the system, I'd rather not wait till I hopefully arrive a decade later on the other side of the fence to be able to do something about it. I would rather make an attempt at being heard now and see whether it makes any progress, even if it just gives some suit on an email thread something to think about. It's not for the sake of my own ego, it's for the sake of our entire breed.

author: LAPhill
content:
Not a dumb question. The distortion on power chords creates an octave below the fundamental pitch, which helps make them feel well, powerful. For intervals other than a 5th, it's not an octave below but some other pitch, and so yeah, you're likely creating unpleasant harmonics outside of the key.

The dumbest, but easiest way to avoid that is to let the bass be the inversion's lowest note while the plays a 5th from the root note. Otherwise, you're looking at dialing back the distortion on those inversions, or on the tone as a whole, which isn't necessarily what's desired.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Copying your favorite songs is actually a great way to learn! I've done it a lot and continue to do it periodically, even after making records for like 25 years. 

Think of this like practice, not as how to make *your* music. Trying to make a note for note, sound for sound copy of a song you like forces you to make moves and choose sounds you otherwise wouldn't choose.

By practicing in this way, you accumulate skills that become part of your subconscious creative arsenal.

Again, at this early point in your journey, there really are no right and wrong ways to make things. The key is to just make as much stuff as you can, trying as many different methods as possible.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Wow. I'm making my way slowly through this Lanois/Beato interview and am amazed by what Lanois is describing from @ 52:24 to 53:45 regarding his approach to stacking modulations and special effects.

As he describes it, he's performing and printing his modulation effects (delay, verb, vibrato, pitch shifting, etc) one generation at a time as he iterates through the song. This allows him to fine-tune and perform the modulations on each successive pass so that every moment is honed and responsive enough that it becomes a part within the music, and not just a blanket effects chain.

So if he's doing pitch-shifted delays, he'll do a pass that goes up a fifth on certain notes and then layer another pass that modulates by a different interval at a select moment instead of leaving everything on throughout the entire section. He's honing each effect in sequence. It shows a tremendous care and sensitivity to the music that he would go through and *perform* each layer with so much intention.

This feels like a revelation to me and I can't wait to practice this.

(I've cued up the video where they start talking about it)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxP9kKzbCFA&t=3144s

The law says "any use" needs to be cleared. One of the major legal cases even specified no minimum length.

author: Slow Hand
content:
One tip I'd give is to make your patch while you have a MIDI sequence playing. Not just some static, even arpeggio that you drew in, but a part that has different articulations, note lengths, velocities, and covers a range of notes.

It's easy when making a patch to just keep your finger on one key and go *doot doot doot* (tweak) *doot doot doot* (tweak again). What you can end up doing this way is optimizing the patch and parameters for a single note or handful of notes. And it gets old to listen to. By keeping the entire musical part playing you're going to move through building a well-balanced patch much quicker.

If you have a part in mind, record the MIDI with your starter/init patch, spend some time tweaking the patch while the sequence plays, and then once you get into the ballpark replay the MIDI part using your new patch. The new synth settings will influence your articulation and feel when you record the second time around. Then refine your patch as needed. Rinse and repeat until you're satisfied.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Any polyphonic subtractive synth should be able to get you there. There's nothing so unique about the sound that you'd need a specific synth model. The characteristic sound of this patch is a saturated LPF with an ADSR filter sweep. It may actually be a monophonic synth with a second oscillator tuned to +7 and blended in at a lower volume. It doesn't sound like they're playing chords, so much as stacked oscillators.

As others mentioned, a Prophet is a good place to start, but it's not going to get you that heavy-grit saturation by itself that we hear on this record. Prophets don't get that dirty on their own. Maybe the Prophet X's with DSP effects will. I haven't used them.

Something like a Moog synth is going to lean heavier into the saturation capabilities. That record feels much more like a Moog filter. A Moog Matriarch is the first thing I'd reach for if it were available to use.

That said, you've probably got enough saturation boxes lying around that you can approximate that grit. But it's a very Moog-y saturation sound.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Easy! FM synthesis is simply vibrato that is super fast (greater than 20 Hz) - and often super deep (a semitone of pitch fluctuation or octaves of it). 

When you modulate the pitch at these rates and depths the vibrato is perceived as new harmonic sidebands that "bloom" out of the oscillator.

Great video.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ehhh it’s more nuanced than that. Automating the mod wheel can drastically change the timbre of an orchestral vst, and is an essential part of humanizing your program, and I think a lot of people don’t really get that. They just open up the abbey road plugin and start hammering out chords. 

A lot of those instruments don’t use velocity info to  change the timbre of the instrument, they rely on the mod wheel, while the velocity means something else (often portamemto, or note glide for the not nerds)

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: I love this sound and a lot of the other stuff that Jockstrap's come up with, and while this is a bit of a non-answer, I think the key is that these sounds are easier to arrive at than they are to aim for. I think a lot of what Taylor Skye is doing is taking sounds and then warping them/distorting them to shit using all of the "wrong" methods, and then just judging what comes out and deciding if it should be kept. I think there's a good hint of this in the lead sound at the start, where it's really out of rhythm and grainy, some notes seem to sort of "break" which reminds me of the results you get when you try to formant shift a verbed-out or polyphonic sound with little alterboy, or even abusing izotope RX on something that doesn't really need it (also, the RX de-reverb can do wild things to a sound you've put reverb on higher in the chain). Logic, which is what he uses, also has a lesser known formant shift that you can only get to by turning on flex pitch then adjusting in the side info bar, which can really take sounds into space. I haven't done this with melodyne, but I imagine there are some similar features.

author: Deleted User
content:
Polyphonic subtractive synth : subtractive synth is a synthesis mechanism that utilizes combination of oscillators and filters. So a synth with Osc, Filter  that can play more than one note at a time

ADSR filter sweep - ADSR is a type of enveloping shape. Attack time, Decay time, Sustain level, and Release time. Sweep here refers to when you make the envelope move the filter corner (cutoff) frequency. It acts like as if you are moving the filter by hand every time a key is triggered. 

Stacked Oscillators : When you have OSC1 and OSC2 tuned differently. In this case Bradley is referring to OSC2 being 7 semitones higher and having it on lower volume relative to OSC1.

author: Adam Thein
content:
It's really simple in Live (and I'm sure there's equivalent warp modes in other daws) - use the Repitch Warp mode, move the tempo down til you are slightly slower (the track will play back at a lower pitch), record at that new key and tempo, and warp it back up (Repitch mode on whatever you recorded).  The formants and the pitch and the tempo will all move together and playback smoothly.

I think @Ross Fortune has mentioned this before but the iOS app MusicMath has a handy tool to input the BPM and how many semitones you want to transpose and it'll kick out the correct new BPM to get the transposition you want.

author: NoahNeedleman
LAPhill
content:
Oooh I have a theory here, about cultural values. Audiences in the 1800s, for instance, could go to a symphonic concert and recognize sonata form, key centers, etc. There was an appreciation for the form of the music and the virtuosity of the player first and foremost. Acknowledgement of skill. Making things seem effortless was the ideal.

Contemporary listeners seem to connect more with the struggle. They want to hear the grit in the vocal, the player at the edge of their ability (whatever it may be) holding on for dear life. The mix at the edge of distortion. In that breaking point, there is a lot of beauty and emotion that would have traditionally been considered bad form. Uncouth, even!

author: Deleted User
content:
Learn what different carrier to modulator ratios sound like by messing with them only using sine waves.  and then feel out what it feels like feedback carrier and/or the modulator. And then you can introduce envelopes to create shapes with them. 

Tool wise- I would start with FM8, it’s pretty much DX7 but without the limitations of routing configuration like it does in Arturia DX7. And then you can learn with arturia DX7 in conjunction with how the different configuration work. +FM8 has patch morphing function which can be VERY useful when it comes to FM sounds. Another cool thing about FM8 is that it shows you all of the sidebands. 

From here, it’s all experimentation

That’s really all you need, FM looks intimidating but it’s really not that difficult. 


linear FM is essentially really fast vibrato. Non linear FM is a fast trill between the two frequencies. AM is essentially fast *unipolar* tremolo, RM is fast *bipolar: meaning it shifts polarity too* tremolo. they all create sonic characters by creating sidebands. 

one thing to keep in mind is most FM synths are actually not FM. it’s actually imitated by doing phase modulation- but results are almost identical. except in actual FM, you get more of the carrier frequency. So FM with a high-pass filtered modulator is essentially the same as PM with a low pass filtered modulator


run down on difference in sidebands between the most common audio-rate modulated synthesis:

FM/PM creates equally spaced sidebands

RM only produces sidebands (carrier frequency + modulator frequency & carrier frequency- modulator frequency)

AM is carrier with side bands of c+m and c-m

author: BatMeckley

I’d give that a shot (the aforementioned mutt lang one note at a time chord theory, which supposedly has been overblown, though I’ve heard guys like MUSE have explored it later on) before you go too haywire looking at dramatic eq moves or what not.

author: LAPhill
content: Why isn't editing possible? If you can't fix the spot in a way that sounds natural, you may need to grab that section from a different part of the track and replace it, if it appears anywhere else. author: Slow Hand
content:
Pick a something from a song that you like and teach it to yourself. Maybe a melody, some chords, or a cool voice leading thing.

As you try it, play around with transposing, changing the tempo, stretching it out, or compressing the time. I find that playing with something like this gets me in the mindset and before long I’m inspired enough to use the idea as a jumping-off point.

content:
In addition to the diamonds like Noah said, just root notes chugging away or playing 8th notes can be helpful and non invasive if chords or power chords feel too informative. Octaves can be a cool halfway point. A lot of songs seem to have room for the clean “dinky” sort of electric parts (sometimes slightly melodic or sometimes just hanging out on a single note).

If it’s a matter of filling space, something that helped me on a pop track the other day was making a second track for echoes of the lead vocal where you can low pass it pretty hard and delay / verb it out.

I often find myself introducing subtle sub basses later in the song, potentially doubling electric bass with synth bass, maybe layering snares to be fatter in later choruses. Then playing with some subtle percussion elements like triangle, clave, wood blocks, to differentiate later choruses.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you're concerned about being too suggestive to the players about their parts then strip back the demo until it contains only the most essential parts. No fancy stuff. Just chords, melody, and lyric. *Maybe* a kick drum pattern. Lead sheet style.

If the song is good then it will still be compelling. The best songs tend to be very robust and can be played a dozen different ways because they are fundamentally compelling. If the demo doesn't feel good this way then the song may need more work.

Lesser songs will depend on the arrangement or production to be compelling, or only work in a narrow band of styles. Sometimes a song can only work one way. It's okay if this is the case for your song, but then it's up to you to present the demo with the arrangement or elements that are essential to make the song compelling, and that will close off more and more of the instrumental possibilities.

So if you want to increase the chances of a session player delivering an unexpected, brilliant, idea then set them up for success with a strong song that can be interpreted many ways.

author: Rollmottle
content: As others have said, recreating a beat you like is the school you need to go to. One of my favorite beats of all time is Fleetwood Mac's "Hypnotized" which is a swingy, triplet unchanging thing that is effectively a drum loop through the song, except Mick Fleetwood plays it. I recreated it using a sample pack of Mick Fleetwood's and turned it into a song after serious finagling, especially in the context of grid music. The insight into accent, velocity, swing, where in the grid things hit (or don't), which specific hits matter and how dropping just one or two key hits in a repetitive pattern can shift the groove entirely. It also tests your chops for figuring out choke groups, how to make closed and open hi hats sound "real" (if that's your goal) so on and so forth. I also love recreating a beat as a way in when musical inspiration may be lacking.

author: Deleted User
content:
the controller is called continuum. I believe it is an mpe (midi polyphonic expressions) device. I don’t know much about kyma but i would look into physical modeling because this is what the sound generation is based on. A lot of physical modeling is heavily based on delay lines, so I’d start there. Modal synthesis is also another cool concept where you would feed an impulse sample into a bank of parallel bandpass filters (very narrow q- which is also constructed with delay lines fundamentally). The idea is feedback and resonance from the filters would emulate acoustic modes. 

You can emulate this with fairly cheap stuff like leap motion, I’ve done a different project (something much simpler) with leap motion for gesture controlled music concrète. But you can definitely use the gestures to do the same thing with physical modeling. I’d be down to work on something together if you’re interested!

author: Slow Hand
content:
(Ok. Now I'm starting to run with this train of thought. Now would be a good time to step off if you've gotten what you need.)

I don't want this to sound like the end-all be-all. One of my absolute favorites is James Brown, and there is no way that some of his songs would hold up to the level of scrutiny I'm describing. And those records *kill*. It's all vibe. It's vibe all the way down, bebe. Not a chord change in sight. Barely a melody in some cases. And that's alright.

So what did James do? More often than not James would get all of his band (real jazz killers) in the studio and he would sing the parts to them one by one and allow them to input their own feel.

He'd start with the drummer and have them play a pattern that James was feeling. Once the drummer was jamming on that he would move on to the bass player and sing them an idea. Once the bass player had that germ of an idea they would continue to jam on it with the drummer, refining and adding their own thing. Then James would move on to the horns, and so on, and so on.

While James could be dictatorial and (from the perspective of music education) the least technically qualified person in the room he had *vision*. 

If the song has a strong identity you can give your players a good (non-technical) prompt and they can interpret that through their own sensibilities. You can describe a mood, or a scene, or an abstract sensation.

R. Kelly once said (I'm paraphrasing): "RnB is supposed to feel like the best moment of your *life*." That simple description conveys so much about the feel, the pleasure, and the joy that he is looking for in his music. It also excludes a lot of possibilities as well. If you can give your players a prompt like *that* then you can get everyone aligned on the same wavelength and it will carry you so much further without the need to dictate parts.

----

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hmmm. I wouldn't say that you *need* a Moog, but they're always a nice color to have in the kit. And it doesn't hurt that they're a "classic" sound, so having one around wouldn't be a bad investment and will likely see a lot of use over the years.

The last generation of Moog synths (from Sub37 onward) have been very gritty and have a lot of options for drive and feedback, which allows them to get very rough, in contrast to the Dave Smith synths which tend to be cleaner, buzzy, and articulate. These days Moogs are very warm, thick, and gritty. They're extremely easy on the ears, even when you're cranking the drive. The core components of Moog sound *really* good and there's a lot of care that's gone into the raw sound of these things. Namely the oscillators and the filter circuit. They are *very* well designed instruments. In fact, I'd say that they're *beautiful* instruments.

My recommendation for someone who's not super-deep into synthesis but wants to own a Moog would be to buy a *Subsequent 37*. It's got digitally recallable presets, whereas *Matriarch* and *Grandmother* are semi-modular and have little/no preset capability. The Subsequent 37 is plug and play, has a great set of unique features, wonderful grit, and is very fun to play.

Keep in mind that the *Subsequent 37* is a monophonic synth. Technically it's paraphonic (can play up to *two* notes at a time), but you're not going to be playing any chords on it like on your Prophet.

content: Maybe there's a solution to this problem where composers still sequence horns the old-fashioned way, using passable MIDI/sample mockups that don't get 100% there. Then the DAW does an offline pass when bouncing where it uses an AI model to fill in the blanks to make the legatos feel convincing. Or maybe it interpolates tongue-slaps into the performance in a way that carries over the resonance from the prior notes, or colors "outside the lines" by injecting a certain amount of "frenzy" into the playing that modulates pitch, intensity, timing, or overall "vibe". Or maybe it makes the timbre "a little more Duke Ellington and less John Williams". Or maybe it renders a double-tracked horn that's not just a pitch-modulated version of the source audio file.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Skyler Young This looks cool. A neat feature I'd love to see someday would be to add a simple EQ device and allow internal resampling of one-shot samples. The idea is that samples often have some boxiness or ringing that needs to be EQ'd out, but those problem-zones shift when the sample is transposed up and down, making any post-sampler EQ moves ineffectual.

If you could streamline the process of re-recording a static sample with the necessary EQ cuts committed into the one-shot then those cuts would be transposed along with the sample when you play it up and down the keyboard.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Josh I owned an NI Maschine+ (the standalone hardware unit) for a year before I eventually sold it. My reasons were much like yours; to get away from software and have a standalone instrument to play with.

I don't have many bad things to say about it, but ultimately it just wasn't a good fit for the way my brain works. NI have crammed a tremendous amount of features and functions into that thing. Most of which it does very well, but when it came time to do sequencing in the unit the interface was just too much of a hurdle for me. I found it hard to keep all of the key commands in my head to do simple commands. I think it's a little *too* efficient in how many options they've fit into it. Remembering the commands among it's unorthodox button layout was challenging and unintuitive for me.

As you might imagine, it integrates perfectly with the Maschine software, which is basically a DAW within a plugin that controls the hardware and vice-versa if you choose to use a computer. But I wasn't interested in that, because I can achieve the same things and more with plain old Ableton.

It *does* have a fantastic sample library and the NI sample packs you can purchase are very well done.

author: Rob Domos
content: To be embarrassingly transparent, a lot of times I think a note is late by listening and then after looking find out it was early. Things just feel in time or out. Also, a lot of things that have loose rhythm in a way that people tend to love often bother me and sound out of time to me. Jay-Z is a perfect example of this. I spent years thinking his rhythm was terrible before I realized he was doing a shuffle time feel where the amount his vocal is off from the snare creates the shuffle. I just didn’t pick up on that for like… 15 years? And just wondered why nobody else was bothered him being “out of time”. Kind of like when people with an undeveloped sense of harmony think of jazz as simply being an excuse for allowing wrong notes. That’s how I hear people that are famous for stretching rhythm

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I'm asking if you want samples of solo string instruments or a string section.

For ensemble I've been enjoying the *NI Session Strings 2*. I've also got the *Spitfire BBC Symphony* but I'm less fond of those because they're recorded from an orchestral perspective and have a lot of room sound baked in, whereas *Session Strings 2* have a closer perspective. If you want an ensemble sound plus some major grit and close-miking I *do* like the *Bernard Hermann* orchestral library from Spitfire.

For solo strings the *NI Cremona Quartet* instruments are really, really nice. They're a pleasure to play with and sound fantastic. These have maximum presence too, so you can get some very direct sounds with them. I'm really enjoying them. The articulation and tonal options are extremely thorough.

A while back a few people recommended *Sunset Strings* by Realitone. While I haven't used it yet, they look very promising. They seem to be serving people who want a rock/pop string feel, which could be just the ticket.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone know if there's a program, synth, or protocol that allows you to modulate synthesizer envelope times based on the duration of the MIDI note?

For example, if I draw a quarter note (on the piano roll) and my synth plays a one octave downward sweep it would take a quarter note's worth of time to execute that sweep. But if I draw a MIDI note with a whole-note duration the synthesizer would modulate it's envelope time and that same sweep would descend over the course of a whole-note.

The synth would have to read upcoming MIDI note lengths from the the piano roll and modulate it's parameters on a note by note basis by reading the note duration before the note-on message. There would have to be some sort of communication between the synth and the DAW, and of course it would not work in real time.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you learn how diatonic chords work it can take you far. Every key has what are called it's diatonic chords. These are chords that are made from the notes in your major or minor scale.

**For example:** In the key of F, your diatonic chords are these:

F, Gm, Am, Bb, C, Dm, E dim.

You can play any of those chords and they'll fit right in. Those are your "can't lose" chords that will sound coherent no matter what. I would start here by chaining some of these chords together and seeing how they sound. They're like words in a sentence that you can rearrange to say different things.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Sort of, yes. But you don't need to take a chunk out of the middle of the note. The slowest way to do it (and the easiest for me to explain) is you just make two edit points: one in the middle of the held note and one after that note is finished. You then move that new clip later, drag out the end of either clip in the new space you just created, line up the waveforms, then add an equal gain crossfade.

There are several combinations of pro tools key commands to achieve this with many fewer clicks than I just described (nudging commands, option clicking and dragging, heal regions, etc), but those are easier to show than tell

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Akanksha Co-sign on what Matt has said here. Learning to write chord progressions is a strong skill to develop. Chords are what gives your song harmonic motion and a sense of going places. They can give it tension and release. A good progression will show you where to take the song next.

Or you can write a melody first and then come up with chords underneath it. Whichever feels more natural to you. No wrong answers here.

author: Rollmottle
content: Yup. I wasn’t trying to equate performing and mixing or even specifically talking about making orchestral VSTs go. Just reacting to the idea that turning off the performance (or mix or songwriting or some other inextricably linked piece of music)  is some major revelation…see how much better it is when it’s performed!? See how much better it is when you work on it!? Well…yeah.
